text: In the eighth month of Darius’ second year as king, the Lord spoke his word to the prophet Zechariah, who was the son of Berechiah and the grandson of Iddo. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord was very angry with your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell the people, ‘This is what the Lord of Armies says: Return to me, declares the Lord of Armies, and I will return to you, says the Lord of Armies.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t be like your ancestors, who heard the earlier prophets preach to them, ‘This is what the Lord of Armies says: Turn from your evil ways and your evil deeds.’ But they didn’t listen or pay attention to me, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your ancestors—where are they now? And the prophets—are they still alive?
speaker: Narrator

text: Didn’t my warnings and my laws, which I’ve commanded my servants the prophets to preach, finally catch up with your ancestors? Then your ancestors turned away from their sins and said, ‘The Lord of Armies has done to us what he had planned to do. He has dealt with us as our ways and deeds deserve.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the twenty-fourth day of the eleventh month (the month of Shebat) in Darius’ second year as king, the Lord spoke his word to the prophet Zechariah, who was the son of Berechiah and the grandson of Iddo.
speaker: Narrator

text: During that night I saw a man riding on a red horse. He was standing among the myrtle trees in a ravine. Behind him were red, chestnut, and white horses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What do these horses mean, sir?” I asked.
The angel who was speaking with me answered, “I will show you what they mean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man standing among the myrtle trees explained, “They’re the horses the Lord has sent to patrol the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they reported to the Messenger of the Lord standing among the myrtle trees, “We have patrolled the earth. The whole world is at rest and in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Messenger of the Lord said, “Lord of Armies, how much longer until you show compassion to Jerusalem and the cities of Judah? You’ve been angry with them for 70 years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord responded to the angel who was speaking with me, using kind and comforting words.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel who was speaking with me said, “Announce: This is what the Lord of Armies says: I’m very jealous about Jerusalem and Zion,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I’m very angry with the nations who think they are at ease. I was only a little angry, but they made things worse.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord of Armies says: I have returned to Jerusalem with compassion. My house will be rebuilt in it, declares the Lord of Armies. A measuring line will be used to rebuild Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Announce again: This is what the Lord of Armies says: My cities will overflow with prosperity once more. The Lord will again comfort Zion and will again choose Jerusalem.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I looked up and saw four animal horns.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I asked the angel who was speaking with me, “What do these horns mean?”
He said to me, “These are the horns of the nations that scattered Judah, Israel, and Jerusalem.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord showed me four craftsmen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I asked, “What are they going to do?”
He answered, “Those horns scattered Judah so widely that no one could lift up his head. But the craftsmen have come to terrify them, to throw down the horns of the nations. The nations raised their horns to scatter the land of Judah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I looked up and saw a man with a measuring line in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I asked him, “Where are you going?”
He answered, “I am going to measure Jerusalem to see how wide and how long it is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel who was speaking with me left. Another angel came out to meet him
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to him, “Run, and say to that young man, ‘Jerusalem will be inhabited like an unwalled village because it will have so many people and animals in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will be a wall of fire around it, declares the Lord. I will be the glory within it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Hurry, hurry! Flee from the land of the north, declares the Lord. I’ve scattered you to the four winds of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hurry, Zion! Escape, you inhabitants of Babylon!
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord of Armies says: Afterwards, the Glory sent me to the nations who looted you. Whoever touches you touches the apple of his eye.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m going to shake my fist at the nations, and their own slaves will loot them. Then you will know that the Lord of Armies has sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sing for joy and rejoice, people of Zion. I’m going to come and live among you, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day many nations will join the Lord and become my people. I will live among you. Then you will know that the Lord of Armies has sent me to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will claim Judah as his own in the holy land and will again choose Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Everyone be silent in the presence of the Lord. He is waking up and setting out from his holy dwelling place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he showed me Joshua, the chief priest, standing in front of the Messenger of the Lord. Satan the Accuser was standing at Joshua’s right side to accuse him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Satan, “I, the Lord, silence you, Satan! I, the Lord, who has chosen Jerusalem, silence you! Isn’t this man like a burning log snatched from a fire?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua was wearing filthy clothes and was standing in front of the Messenger.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Messenger said to those who were standing in front of him, “Remove Joshua’s filthy clothes.” Then he said to Joshua, “See, I have taken your sin away from you, and I will dress you in fine clothing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I said, “Put a clean turban on his head.” They put a clean turban on his head and dressed him while the Messenger of the Lord was standing there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Messenger of the Lord advised Joshua,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord of Armies says: If you live according to my ways and follow my requirements, you will govern my temple and watch over my courtyards. Then I will give you free access to walk among those standing here.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Listen, Chief Priest Joshua and your friends sitting with you. These men are a sign of things to come: I’m going to bring my servant, the Branch.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look at the stone I have set in front of Joshua. That one stone has seven eyes. I am engraving an inscription on it,” declares the Lord of Armies. “I will remove this land’s sin in a single day.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day,” declares the Lord of Armies, “each of you will invite your neighbor to sit under your vine and fig tree.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel who was speaking with me returned and woke me up as one might wake up someone who is sleeping.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He asked me, “What do you see?”
I answered, “I see a solid gold lamp stand with a bowl on top and seven lamps on it. There are seven spouts for each lamp that is on top of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are also two olive trees beside it, one on the right of the bowl and the other on its left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I asked the angel who was speaking with me, “What do these things mean, sir?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the angel asked me, “Don’t you know what they mean?”
“No, sir,” I answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he replied, “This is the word the Lord spoke to Zerubbabel: You won’t succeed by might or by power, but by my Spirit, says the Lord of Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text: What a high mountain you are! In front of Zerubbabel you will become a plain. He will bring out the topmost stone with shouts of ‘Blessings, blessings on it!’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Zerubbabel’s hands have laid the foundation of this house, and his hands will finish it. Then you will know that the Lord of Armies has sent me to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who despised the day when little things began to happen? They will be delighted when they see the plumb line in Zerubbabel’s hand. (These seven eyes of the Lord roam over all the earth.)”
speaker: Narrator

text: I asked the angel, “What do these two olive trees at the right and the left of the lamp stand mean?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again I asked him, “What is the meaning of the two branches from the olive trees next to the two golden pipes that are pouring out gold?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He asked me, “Don’t you know what these things mean?”
“No, sir,” I answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said, “These are the two anointed ones who are standing beside the Lord of the whole earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I looked up again and saw a flying scroll.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The angel asked me, “What do you see?”
“I see a flying scroll,” I answered. “It’s 30 feet long and 15 feet wide.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to me, “This is a curse that will go out all over the earth. The one side of the scroll says that every thief will be forced away. The other side of the scroll says that everyone who takes an oath will be forced away.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send out a curse, declares the Lord of Armies, and it will enter the houses of thieves and the houses of those who take oaths in my name. It will stay in their houses and destroy the timber and stone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel who was speaking with me came forward. He said, “Look up, and see what’s coming.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What is it?” I asked.
“A basket is coming,” he said. Then he added, “This is what the people’s sins look like all over the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: A lead cover on the basket was raised, and a woman was sitting in the basket.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel said, “This is wickedness,” and he pushed her back into the basket and forced the lead cover down on top of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I looked up and saw two women coming forward with wind in their wings. They had wings like those of a stork. They carried the basket into the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text: I asked the angel who was speaking with me, “Where are they taking the basket?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered me, “They are going to build a house for it in Shinar [Babylonia]. When the house is ready, they will set the basket there on a stand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I looked up again and saw four chariots going out from between the two mountains. They were mountains of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first chariot had red horses. The second had black horses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The third had white horses. And the fourth had strong, spotted horses.
speaker: Narrator

text: I asked the angel who was speaking with me, “What do these horses mean, sir?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel answered, “They are the four spirits of heaven. They are going out after standing in the presence of the Lord of the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The chariot with the black horses is going toward the north, and the white horses are following them. The spotted ones are going toward the south.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When these strong horses went out, they were eager to patrol the earth.
He said, “Go, patrol the earth!” And they patrolled the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he called out to me, “Look! Those who went to the north have made my Spirit rest in the north.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take an offering from the exiles Heldai, Tobijah, and Jedaiah, who have arrived from Babylon. This same day go to the house of Josiah, son of Zephaniah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the silver and gold, make a crown, and put it on the head of Chief Priest Joshua, son of Jehozadak.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then say to him, ‘This is what the Lord of Armies says: Here is the man whose name is Branch. He will branch out from where he is, and he will rebuild the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will rebuild the Lord’s temple and receive royal honor. He will sit and rule from his throne. He will be a priest on his throne. There will be a peaceful understanding between them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The crown will be a reminder to Helem, Tobijah, Jedaiah, and Hen (son of Zephaniah) in the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who are far away will come and rebuild the Lord’s temple. Then you will know the Lord of Armies has sent me to you. This will happen if you obey the Lord your God completely.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fourth day of the ninth month (the month of Chislev) in Darius’ fourth year as king, the Lord spoke his word to Zechariah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, the people from Bethel sent Sharezer and Regem Melech with their men  to ask the Lord for a blessing.
speaker: Narrator

text: They asked the priests from the house of the Lord of Armies as well as the prophets, “Should we mourn and fast in the fifth month as we have done for so many years?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord of Armies spoke his word to me. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell all the people of the land and the priests, ‘When you fasted and mourned in the fifth and seventh months these past 70 years, did you really do it for me?
speaker: Narrator

text: When you ate and drank, didn’t you do it to benefit yourselves?
speaker: Narrator

text: Aren’t these the same words that the Lord announced through the earlier prophets, when Jerusalem and its surrounding cities were inhabited and undisturbed and the Negev and the foothills were still inhabited?’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke his word to Zechariah. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord of Armies says: Administer real justice, and be compassionate and kind to each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t oppress widows, orphans, foreigners, and poor people. And don’t even think of doing evil to each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But people refused to pay attention. They shrugged their shoulders at me and shut their ears so that they couldn’t hear.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made their hearts as hard as flint so that they couldn’t hear the Lord’s teachings, the words that the Lord of Armies had sent by his Spirit through the earlier prophets. So the Lord of Armies became very angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When I called, they wouldn’t listen. So now when they call, I won’t listen, says the Lord of Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text: I used a windstorm to scatter them among all the nations, nations they hadn’t even heard of. They left behind a land so ruined that no one is able to travel through it. They have turned a pleasant land into a wasteland.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord of Armies spoke his word.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says:
I am very jealous about Zion.
I am fiercely possessive of it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
I will return to Zion and live in Jerusalem.
Jerusalem will be called the City of Truth.
The mountain of the Lord of Armies will be called the holy mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says:
Old men and old women will again sit in the streets of Jerusalem.
Each will have a cane in hand because of old age.
speaker: Narrator

text: The city will be filled with boys and girls playing in the streets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says:
It may seem impossible to the few remaining people in those days,
but will it seem impossible to me? declares the Lord of Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says:
I am going to save my people
from the land where the sun rises
and from the land where the sun sets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will bring them back, and they will live in Jerusalem.
They will be my people, and I will be their God, who is faithful and just.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says:
Be strong so that the temple might be rebuilt,
you people who are presently listening
to the words from the mouths of the prophets
who spoke when the foundation
for the house of the Lord of Armies was laid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before that time there was no money to hire any person or animal.
No one who traveled was safe from the enemy.
I turned every person against his neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now I won’t deal with the few remaining people
as I did in earlier times, declares the Lord of Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Seeds will thrive in peacetime.
Vines will produce their grapes.
The land will yield its crops.
The sky will produce its dew.
I will give the few remaining people
all these things as an inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just as you, people of Judah and people of Israel,
have been a curse among the nations,
so I will now save you,
and you will become a blessing.
Don’t be afraid. Let your hands work hard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says:
When your ancestors made me angry,
I made plans to destroy you, declares the Lord of Armies,
and I didn’t change my plans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So now I have again made plans, but this time to do good
to Jerusalem and the people of Judah.
Don’t be afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You must do these things:
Speak the truth to each other.
Give correct and fair verdicts for peace in your courts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t even think of doing evil to each other.
Don’t enjoy false testimony.
I hate all these things, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord of Armies spoke his word to me again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says:
The fast in the fourth month, the fast in the fifth month,
the fast in the seventh month, and the fast in the tenth month
will become joyful and glad occasions
as well as happy festivals for the nation of Judah.
So love truth and peace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says:
People and citizens from many cities are going to come.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The citizens of one city will come to another city, saying,
“Let’s make a habit of going to ask the Lord for a blessing
and to seek the Lord of Armies.
I’m also going.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many people and powerful nations will come
to seek the Lord of Armies in Jerusalem
and to ask the Lord for a blessing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord of Armies says:
In those days ten people from every language found among the nations
will take hold of the clothes of a Jew. They will say,
“Let us go with you
because we have heard that God is with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the divine revelation.
The Lord’s word is against the land of Hadrach
and will rest on Damascus
speaker: Narrator

text:
and also Hamath, which borders on it,
and Tyre and Sidon, though they are very wise.
(The eyes of humanity and of all the tribes of Israel are on the Lord.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tyre built itself a fortress.
It piled up silver like dust
and gold like mud in the streets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will take away its possessions.
He will throw its wealth into the sea
and burn the city down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ashkelon will see this and be afraid.
Gaza will also be in great pain,
also Ekron, because its hope will fade.
Gaza will lose its king.
Ashkelon will no longer be lived in.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A mixed race will live in Ashdod,
and I will cut off the Philistines’ arrogance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will remove the blood from their mouths
and the disgusting things from between their teeth.
Then only a few of them will be left for our God
like a tribe in Judah,
and Ekron will be like a Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will camp in front of my house
as a guard against those who come and go.
No oppressors will pass through them,
because I have seen it with my own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rejoice with all your heart, people of Zion!
Shout in triumph, people of Jerusalem!
Look! Your King is coming to you:
He is righteous and victorious.
He is humble and rides on a donkey,
on a colt, a young pack animal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He  will make sure there are no chariots in Ephraim
or war horses in Jerusalem.
There will be no battle bows.
He will announce peace to the nations.
He will rule from sea to sea
and from the Euphrates River to the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will set your captives free from the waterless pit
because of the blood that sealed my promise  to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Return to your fortress, you captives who have hope.
Today I tell you that I will return to you double blessings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will bend Judah as my bow
and draw my bow with Ephraim as its arrow.
I will stir up your people, Zion, against your people, Greece,
and I will use you like a warrior’s sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will appear over them,
and his arrow will go out like lightning.
The Almighty Lord will blow the ram’s horn
and will march in the storms from the south.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord of Armies will defend them.
They will destroy and trample the stones used in slings.
They will drink and shout as if they were drunk.
They will be filled like a sacrificial bowl
used for sprinkling the corners of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On that day the Lord their God will rescue them
as the flock of his people.
They will certainly sparkle in his land like jewels in a crown.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will be beautiful and lovely.
Young men will prosper on grain,
and young women will prosper on new wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ask the Lord for rain in the springtime.
The Lord makes thunderstorms.
He gives everyone rain showers for the plants in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The idols speak lies.
The fortunetellers see false visions.
They speak about false dreams.
They give useless comfort.
That is why people wander around like sheep.
They are troubled because there is no shepherd.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My burning anger is directed against the shepherds.
I will punish the male goats.
The Lord of Armies takes care of his flock, the people of Judah.
He makes them like his splendid war horse.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Together they will be like warriors
who trample the enemy in the mud on the streets.
They will fight because the Lord is with them.
They will put to shame those who ride on horses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will strengthen the people of Judah.
I will rescue Joseph’s people.
I will bring them back, because I have compassion for them.
It will be as though I had never rejected them,
because I am the Lord their God, and I will answer them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people of Ephraim will be like mighty warriors.
Their hearts will be glad as if they had some wine to drink.
Their sons will see it and be glad.
Their hearts will find joy in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will signal them with a whistle
and gather them because I have reclaimed them.
They will be as numerous as they have ever been.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Although I have scattered them among the nations,
they will remember me even in faraway places.
They will live with their children and then return.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will bring them back from Egypt.
I will gather them from Assyria.
I will bring them to Gilead and to Lebanon,
and there won’t be enough room for them.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will pass through a sea of distress,
strike the waves in the sea,
and dry up all the deep places of the Nile River.
The pride of Assyria will be humiliated,
and the scepter of Egypt will depart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will strengthen them in the Lord.
They will live in his name,” declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Open your doors, Lebanon,
so that fire will be able to burn down your cedars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cry, cypress trees,
because the cedars have fallen
and the stately trees have been destroyed.
Cry, oak trees of Bashan,
because your dense forest has fallen down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen! The shepherds are crying,
because their rich pastures are destroyed.
Listen! The young lions are roaring,
because the lush banks of the Jordan are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord my God says: Take care of the sheep that are about to be slaughtered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who buy them will kill them and go unpunished. Those who sell them will say, “Praise the Lord! I’ve become rich!” Even their own shepherds will have no pity on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord declares, “I will no longer have pity on those who live in the land. I am going to hand the people over to their neighbors and their king, who will crush the land. And I won’t rescue any of them from their power.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I became the shepherd of the sheep that were to be slaughtered and also of the oppressed sheep. I took two shepherd staffs and named one Favor and the other Unity. And I took care of the sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: I got rid of three shepherds in one month. I became impatient with the sheep, and they also became disgusted with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I said, “I won’t be your shepherd. Let those that are dying die. Let those that are missing stay missing. And let those that are left devour each other.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I took my staff called Favor and broke it in pieces, to break the promise  that I had made to all the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it was broken on that day, and the oppressed among the sheep who were watching me realized that it was the Lord’s word.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said to them, “If it’s alright with you, pay me my wages. But if it’s not, don’t.” And they paid me my wages—30 pieces of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told me, “Give it to the potter.” So I took the 30 pieces of silver. Such a magnificent price was set by them! I gave the pieces of silver to the potter at the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I broke my second staff, called Unity, in pieces, to break off the brotherhood between Judah and Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, “Use the equipment of a foolish shepherd again.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m about to place a shepherd in the land. He will not take care of those that are dying. He will not search for the young. He will not heal those that have broken their legs or support those that can still stand. But he will eat the meat of the fat animals and tear off their hoofs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How horrible it will be for the foolish shepherd who abandoned the sheep.
A sword will strike his arm and his right eye.
His arm will be completely withered.
His right eye will be completely blind.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the prophetic revelation, the Lord’s word about Israel. The Lord—who spread out the heavens, laid the foundation of the earth, and forms the spirit in a person—says,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m going to make Jerusalem like a cup of wine that makes all the surrounding people stagger. They will attack Judah along with Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day I will make Jerusalem a stone too heavy for all the nations to lift. All who try to lift it will be severely injured. All the nations in the world will gather to fight against Jerusalem.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord declares, “On that day I will strike every horse with panic and every rider with madness. I will watch over the people of Judah, but I will strike all the horses of the nations blind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the leaders of Judah will think to themselves, ‘The people who live in Jerusalem are strong because of the Lord of Armies, their God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “On that day I will make the leaders of Judah like a fire on a pile of wood and like a burning torch among freshly cut straw. They will burn up all the surrounding nations to the right and to the left. But the people of Jerusalem will remain safe in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will save Judah’s tents first so that the honor of David’s family and the honor of those who live in Jerusalem will not be greater than the honor of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the Lord will defend those who live in Jerusalem so that even those who stumble will be like David, and David’s family will be like God, like the Messenger of the Lord ahead of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On that day I will seek to destroy all the nations who attack Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will pour out the Spirit of blessing and mercy on David’s family and on those who live in Jerusalem. They will look at me, whom they have stabbed. Then they will mourn for him as one mourns for an only son, and they will cry bitterly for him as one cries for a firstborn son.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the mourning in Jerusalem will be as intense as the mourning at Hadad Rimmon in the plain of Megiddo.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land will mourn, each family by itself: the family of David by itself, and the wives by themselves; the family of Nathan by itself, and the wives by themselves;
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of Levi by itself, and the wives by themselves; the family of Shimei by itself, and the wives by themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the families that are left will mourn, each by itself, and the wives by themselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord declares, “On that day a fountain will be opened for David’s family and for those who live in Jerusalem to wash away their sin and stain.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On that day,” declares the Lord of Armies, “I will wipe away the names of the idols from the land. They will no longer be remembered. I will also remove the false prophets and the unclean  spirit from the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man still prophesies, his father and his mother, who gave birth to him, will say, ‘You don’t deserve to live because you speak lies in the name of the Lord.’ Then his father and his mother, who gave birth to him, will stab him when he prophesies.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On that day every prophet will be ashamed of his vision when he prophesies. He won’t deceive people by dressing like a prophet in a coat made of hair.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will say, ‘I am not a prophet. I’m a farmer. I’ve owned this land since I was a child.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “When someone asks him, ‘What are these scars on your chest?’ he will answer, ‘I was hurt at my friend’s house.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Arise, sword, against my shepherd,
against the man who is my friend,” declares the Lord of Armies.
“Strike the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered.
Then I will turn my hand against the little ones.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord declares,
“Throughout the land two-thirds will be cut off and die.
Yet, one-third will be left in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will bring this third of the people through the fire.
I will refine them as silver is refined.
I will test them as gold is tested.
They will call on me, and I will answer them.
I will say, ‘They are my people.’
They will reply, ‘The Lord is our God.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: A day is going to come for the Lord when the loot you have taken will be divided among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will gather all the nations to Jerusalem for battle. The city will be captured, the houses looted, and the women raped. Half of the people in the city will go into exile, but the rest of the people won’t be taken from the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord will go out and fight against those nations as he does when he fights a battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day his feet will stand on the Mount of Olives, just east of Jerusalem. The Mount of Olives will be split in two, forming a very large valley from east to west. Half of the mountain will move toward the north, and the other half will move toward the south.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will flee to the valley of my mountains, because this valley between the mountains will go as far as Azel. You will flee as you did from the earthquake at the time of King Uzziah of Judah. The Lord my God will come, and all the holy ones will be with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day there will be neither heat nor freezing cold.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be one day—a day known to the Lord—with no difference between day and night. It will be light even in the evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day living water will flow out from Jerusalem, half of it to the Dead Sea and the other half to the Mediterranean Sea. It will continue in summer and in winter.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will be king over all the earth. On that day the Lord will be the only Lord and his name the only name.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole earth will become like the plains from Geba to Rimmon, south of Jerusalem. Jerusalem will rise and remain on its site, from Benjamin Gate to the place of First Gate, Corner Gate, and from the Tower of Hananel to the king’s winepresses.
speaker: Narrator

text: People will live there, and it will never be threatened with destruction. Jerusalem will live securely.
speaker: Narrator

text: This will be the plague the Lord will use to strike all the people from the nations that have gone to war against Jerusalem. Their flesh will rot while they are standing on their feet. Their eyes will rot in their sockets, and their tongues will rot in their mouths.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day a large-scale panic from the Lord will spread among them. One person will grab the hand of another, and one will attack the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah will also fight in Jerusalem. The wealth of all the surrounding nations will be collected, a very large amount of gold, silver, and clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: A similar plague will also affect horses, mules, camels, donkeys, and all other animals in those camps.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who is left from all the nations that attacked Jerusalem will come every year to worship the king, the Lord of Armies, and to celebrate the Festival of Booths.
speaker: Narrator

text: If any of the families on the earth won’t go to Jerusalem to worship the king, the Lord of Armies, then rain won’t fall on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the people of Egypt won’t go or enter Jerusalem, then rain won’t fall on them. The plague the Lord uses to strike the nations will affect those who won’t come to celebrate the Festival of Booths.
speaker: Narrator

text: This will be the punishment for Egypt’s sin and for the sin of all the nations that won’t go to celebrate the Festival of Booths.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day “Holy to the Lord” will be written on the bells of the horses. And the cooking pots in the house of the Lord will be like the bowls in front of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, every pot in Jerusalem and in Judah will be holy to the Lord of Armies. All who come to sacrifice will take some of them and cook in them. On that day there will no longer be any Canaanite  in the house of the Lord of Armies.
speaker: Narrator
